intro: Omphalopus fallax var. novoguineensis, commonly known as the New Guinea bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of New Guinea. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, white to violet flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant typically grows as a herbaceous perennial, often reaching heights of up to 60 cm. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and slightly hairy, while its stems are erect and branched. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forest understories or along stream banks.
